April arrives, and suddenly I’m back to being a junior developer—not because of code, but taxes.

You know the drill: you’ve shipped features, debugged systems, and refactored production issues… yet when it comes to filing your ITR, you're stumped.

The portal glitches, the forms update, and those mysterious pre-filled entries?

Nobody explained what they meant—or why they mattered. Meanwhile, your CA quotes a steep fee or involves multiple back-and-forth rounds, and you're left trusting numbers you don't fully understand.

This time, I treated my ITR filing like a production issue and I found Prosperr.io.

Their AI-powered approach was like finding the optimal solution:

✅ Reduced tax liability to ₹8.5 Lakhs (found the bug in my CA's logic)
✅ Execution time for ITR filing: 1 week vs 4 weeks
✅ Error rate: 0% vs my CA's multiple back-and-forth

The result?

Used saved money to upgrade my entire dev setup and to invest in upskilling my financial knowledge.

Here's what I learned:

We solve complex distributed systems daily but accept 'taxes are hard' as final answer.

We debug production issues in minutes but let CAs run inefficient tax algorithms on our money. We optimize for performance everywhere except our own finances.

It’s high time now to apply a competitive programming mindset to your taxes as well.

Wearing glasses sounds simple.
Until you’re cleaning them 5 times a day.

Every spec-wearer knows that routine:

One accidental touch → Smudge.
One auto ride → Dust.
One oily dish → Goodbye, clean lens.

So when I scanned the AR-enabled newspaper ad by ZEISS Vision,
I didn’t expect much beyond the tech novelty.

But then I saw what they built — the ZEISS Gold lens coating — and instantly wanted to try it.

Because it promised:
✔ Smudge resistance
✔ Easy-to-clean surface
✔ Less glare
✔ A gold reflection that actually looked premium, not flashy

And when you’re on Zoom, in traffic, or on the go — it actually makes a difference.

We upgrade our phones every year.
Maybe it’s time we upgraded our vision too?

hashtag#ZEISSGoldCoating hashtag#ZEISSLenses hashtag#ZEISSVision hashtag#PaidCollab
hashtag#ClearHassleFreeVision hashtag#EverydayUpgrade

But I’d still debate that I haven’t written for industries. I have written for people.

Four years into it. I have written for people, and many.

I somehow manage to write their story the way they wanted to convey.

Ghostwriting is not about how many people in your specific industry I have written for.

I believe in building communities of trust and connection, and I believe in building them on stories.

Not the imaginary ones, but thousands of stories and incidents of the one true story you have lived and you continue to do so.

Every incident, achievement, and setback you have had is a story, and if you ask me, how many stories I’ve written, and how many of them have touched hearts?

I’m slowly letting myself believe what people say about them; I’ve written plenty.

From travel tech to recruitment, from wellbeing to consulting businesses to agencies, there are a handful of industries I can count.

But I’d still debate that I haven’t written for industries. I have written for people.

I help people in business tell their story to the world, exactly the way they would want.

What industry they are in doesn’t matter a lot to me.

If you’re ready to share your story with the world, I’m ready to help you.

I am... not okay.

Not today.

But I'm also not resentful, or ungrateful. Neither do I hate my life.

When you wake up sick on a day, how you feel about your life, is the most honest answer of 'if the life you're building for yourself is for you or not'.

I'm cranky, and have zero energy in my body, but I'm not without joy or will to jot down words, or to be present for the most important of the work.

Nobody is forcing me to write this, I don't bow to the algo gods when I'm ill. But I write because I want to. For a fact, I have at times gotten sick, when I didn't write for days.

And if you're also spending your life doing something that doesn't make you hate your life, on a sick day, well that's the whole point.

Let nothing make you forget that.

PS: Reading for me is not a hobby anymore either, it has become a second nature. Which wasn't the case two years ago. So I'll count that as an achievement.

Okay, I'll be getting inside your brain for a second. So keep on.

No matter who you are, and what you do.

There will come a point in your journey, if you create anything in any way, shape or form.

Where you'll feel this urge to get validation and acknowledgement from creators who are doing better than you, who are in some way or form, better than you.

Nobody really talks about it but the game of creative validation is a hell-hole.

If you're there or when you'll get there, you will make yourself believe, that what you're doing doesn't really matter, until theirs' an approval from people you appreciate in your industry.

You might even start creating, or try to create from their POV, if it's something they will appreciate.

When you do find yourself there. Choose to ignore that voice at any cost.

Choose to do it for yourself.
Choose to do it for your audience.
Choose to do it in a way that works for you.
And in some cases, choose to do it in a way that works for your next month's rent.

And I say this, because I know it's universal, it's hard to admit, and it's envy in its worst form.

And because I have been there, done that. And have left it far behind. Would not recommend.

When you live in a world as cruel as this, you're bound to question the point of all of it.

If you have a heart. If you're human. Not everyone with flesh and bones is one. You figure that out too. You're bound to.

You wake up one day and see people suffering on the other side of the world, when you very well know, your side of the world has it same or worse.

You go on the internet to find an escape from it, and then you lose it again, over abuse, injustice, discrimination, and ignorance.

Then you wake up another day, innocent people killed in the name of religion, hate, and inhumanity.

You feel unexplainable rage & pain for things that are not in your control, that nobody is doing anything to make it all right, all at once. At people, strangers, for not seeing what's right in front of them, in plain sight. For being so naive, or too arrogant to see it.

And if you have a heart, you're going to feel it all, and then, helpless.

You see, humanity, human lives become a propaganda, a trend. You see a part of the world become numb, and another going into shambles.

And then, no matter what anyone says about how, one voice has the power to change the world. You feel so small. So insignificant. So sure that we are all doomed, how will what I do or say make a difference?

I don't think there's much chance, but if you decide to write, speak about something so sensitive, make sure you don't do it for the trend. Make sure it's not just a fleeting trend in your mind as it is for the internet.

There aren't many things more inhumane than that.

We didn't ask for this world, did we?

Until today, I have been too scared to go on podcasts or live events, that people reached out to me for.

I convinced myself that I'm a writer, I help people tell their story day in and out. Writing about it on LinkedIn is one thing, I've been writing on the internet since i was 18. I know how this works.

But I was never too sure how speaking on camera live with 30, 50 or 100 people would be like.

So I've left podcast invitations on seen sometimes, other times I've politely refused for events and webinar. Not very proud of it.

But I finally took the leap today, I'm writing this after speaking at my first ever webinar.

After answering people's questions, and addressing their doubts. It wasn't my best but it was surely best for a first time.

So, I'm ready for it. If you ever thought of inviting me to a podcast, or an event for anything related to personal branding or LinkedIn, you know where to find me.

If you were in the event and want to reach out for work, questions, or queries. I'll be sharing my calendly link in the comments.

PS: A big thanks to Darshankaur Khalsa and my one hell of a support system & boyfriend, who listened to me 100 times what I spoke in the event before I spoke in the event.

I used to spend 2+ hours a day on lead gen...

(Here's how to do it in 10 mins daily)

And no.. I’m not using bots or spammy hacks.
Just a much (MUCH MUCH) tighter process.

Because most creators are burnt out.

- They write 'Hey there 👋' 27 times a day
- They scroll through 15 profiles hoping 1 is a fit
- They comment to stay relevant (but sound like a robot)

It’s soul-sucking. And it doesn’t work fyi.

In 2024, I knew I couldn’t keep up with this bs.
Every day felt like a literal sprint to be seen.

But still...no leads. So I rebuilt everything.

Here's how I now get leads in <10 minutes/day:

↓

1. Pre-qualified lead validation
↳ AI tells me who’s a fit before I waste time

2. Pre-written comment/content bank
↳ 20+ warm comments + content that don’t sound AI

3. Quality DM scripts (well researched ones)
↳ So I can start conversations without being ignored

This isn’t lead gen. It’s systemised visibility.

That actually leads to deals.

P.S. You doing random outreach every day? Or are you doing what actually gets replies? I just helped book my client 2 calls in their FIRST week of outreach using this system. DM me 'ELITE' to know more.

So you’re posting content and waiting for the leads to come in.

And now you’re wondering:

'Why TF isn’t this working like it used to?'

Let me break it to you gently (SCREAMS):

LinkedIn has changed.

- The organic reach isn’t what it was in 2024
- The inbound gold rush? Has pretty much dried up
- The ‘I post and get leads’ pipeline? Shrinking very fast

Even creators who were thriving on inbound…

Started struggling (I did, won't lie at all)

- Impressions dipped
- DM replies slowed down
- Sales calls dropped off a cliff

Here’s what’s real now ↓

Good content still works (no denying that)

But it’s not scalable without one thing:

DMs.

Because content brings awareness.
But DMs bring ACTUAL action.

You want clients?

You can’t wait around for someone to 'see your post'
And then magically message you.

- You need to start the conversation.
- You need to know who to really talk to.
- You need to ask for the sale strategically.

That’s how we:

1. Get 2-3 leads/week for a cold email agency
2. Book 1-2 sales calls/day for a Data Company
3. Booked 3-4 investor calls/week for a niche startup

ALL WEEKLY BTW.

Inbound isn’t dead.

But relying on it only? Is the reason your calendar is empty.

That’s where we at Booked & Built come in.

A) We build your DM + content system
B) We qualify your lead list on the basis of intent
C) We install a flow that brings you 4-6 calls/week

You want to scale without begging the algorithm?

Either start your DM's today struggle for a month and quit

OR

DM me 'Built' and let us help you scale to 4-6 calls/week in the next 2 weeks.
